[0248] FIG. 18 Epithelial Lining Fluid (ELF) Glutathione (GSH) Concentrations and Lung MRP2 and CFTR Expression in Pseudomonas Infected Wild Type Mice.

Wild type (C57/B6) mice were infected with Pseudomonas aeruginosa via infratracheal instillation of Pseudomonas-coated particles. Forty-eight hours following the inoculation, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) and lung tissue were harvested. ELF concenfrations of GSH were calculated from BALF concentrations multiplied by a dilution factor derived from the difference in serum and BALF urea concentrations.

Lungs were lavaged through a fracheal canula with three separate 1 mL aliquots of phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4). Each aliquot was instilled into the lung and withdrawn only once. All three aliquots were then pooled and centrifuged at 4000 xg to remove cells (i.e., alveolar macrophages). The cell-free BALF was acidified with metaphosphoric acid to a final concentration of 0.75% metaphosphoric acid and centrifuged at 20,000 xg to pellet the precipitated proteins. GSH concentrations were determined specfrophotometrically with a commercially available assay that forms a chromogen with GSH. Lungs from Pseudomonas infected mice were homogenized in membrane isolation buffer (250 mM sucrose, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5; MIB) and filtered through silk to remove large debris. Homogenate was then centrifuged at 33,000 xg to pellet membranes. Membranes were resuspended in MLB for Western blotting.
Membrane proteins (30 μg) were separated on 8% agarose gels, transfened to PVDF membranes for determination of MRP2 and CFTR expression. GSH concentrations in the ELF of pseudomonas infected mice (1282 + 238 μM) were significantly elevated compared to uninfected control mice (201 + 75 μM). Data are shown as the mean ± standard enor for n = 5 with significance attained at p ≤ 0.05. Western blots demonsfrate an increase in the expression of both MRP2 and CFTR in pseudomonas infected lungs compared to uninfected mice.
Techniques used in Experimentation

[0249] Serum and BALF Urea Concentrations. To determine actual ELF concentrations of soluble antioxidants from BALF, a dilution factor is derived from the difference between BALF and serum urea concenfrations. The assumption that urea freely diffuses between the vascular and ELF compartments are used as an indicator of ELF dilution. (Rennard, S.I. Estimation of volume of epithelial lining fluid recovered by lavage using urea as a marker of dilution, J. of Applied Physiol. 1986 vol. 60 532-550). A dilution factor is thereby obtained by dividing the serum urea concentration by the BALF concentration. ELF concentrations are then calculated by multiplying the BALF concenfrations by the dilution factor. Urea concenfrations in the samples are determined using a commercially available reagent (Sigma Diagnostics 66-20; St. Louis, MO).

[0250] Western Blot. Lung apoprotein levels of CFTR, MRP-2 and MDR-1 may be determined by western blot analysis. Frozen and fresh lung tissue will be homogenized and 10-30 μg of protein separated by SDS-PAGE (8% acrylamide gels) on a mini protean-3 electrophoresis system at 100 V. Proteins will be transfened onto PVDF membrane and blocked overnight at 4°C with 5% horse serum in Tris balanced salt solution with tween-20 (TBS-T). Proteins will be identified using commercial antibodies against CFTR (monoclonal 24-1, R&D Systems), MRP-2 (monoclonal M2 III-6, Alexis) and MDR-1 (monoclonal 265/F4, NeoMarkers) as primary antibodies that are incubated at room temperature for 2-3 hours, washed extensively with TBS-T and then incubated with the appropriate secondary rabbit antimouse or other antibody conjugated with HRP for 30 minutes at room temperature. Blots are then extensively washed with TBS-T and
developed with an ECL chemiluminescence kit (Amersham) and captured on X-ray film. Densitometry is performed with a gel imaging system (CDD Bio, Hitachi).

[0251] RT-PCR Analysis. RT-PCR will be performed using Advantage one-step kit with a RT-PCR control amplimer set containing mouse G3PDH (Clontech). The primer sequences for the mouse MDR1 gene (5'-CTCACCAAGCGACTCCGATACATG-3'; 5'-GATAATTCCTGTGCCAAGGTTTGCTAC-3') and (5'- AAGACAAAGATTCTAGTGTTGGACG-3');

(5'-AGATATGCCAGAGATCAGTTCACACC-3') for the MRP-2 gene will be used as described(50). RT-PCR products are visualized by UV illumination after electrophoresis through 2% agarose gels and documented using the gel imaging system (CCD Bio, Hitachi).

[0252] Immunocytochemistry. An immunoperoxidase method (Oury et.al 1994. "Immunocytochemical localization of extracellular superoxide dismutase in human lung". Lab Invest. 70:889-898) will be used for light microscopic immunocytochemical labeling. Tissue nonspecific binding to antibodies is blocked by incubation with 5% normal goat seram, 5% gelatin and 1% BSA. Sections are then incubated with either the pre-immune serum or the primary antibody against either MRP-2 or MDR-1 in 0.1% gelatin and 1% BSA in PBS for 1 hour at room temperature. They are washed and incubated with biotin labeled rabbit anti-mouse diluted in 0.1% gelatin and 1% BSA for 1 hour. The labeling signals are intensified by incubation with streptavidin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase in 0.1% gelatin + 1% BSA. Labeling is detected by incubating in diaminobenzidine (10 mg diaminobenzine, 50 ml 0.05 M Tris CI, pH 7.6, 100 μl 3% H O2). After the incubation, slides are counter stained with 1% methyl green, washed, dehydrated in ethanol, cleared with xylene and mounted in flowtek.

[0253] 5. Aconitase Activity. Aconitase inactivation is a sensitive marker for superoxide or peroxynitrite formation in the mitochondria. Aconitase activity is measured specfrophotometrically by monitoring the formation of cis-aconitate from isocitrate at 240 nm as previously described by Patel et.al. 1996 "Requirement for superoxide in excitotoxic cell death . Neuron 16:345-355)
[0254] 6. F2-Isoprostane Formation. The formation of F2-isoprostanes will be measured by GC/MS (gas chromatography/ mass spectroscopy) as previously described. Briefly, F2-isoprostanes will be extracted from tissue with chloro form/methanol (2:1, v/v) containing 0.005% butylated hydroxytoluene and the organic phase evaporated to dryness under vacuum. The F2-isoprostanes will be released from the lipids by hydrolysis in 4 ml methanol plus 4 ml KOH (15%) at 37°C for 30 minutes. The free isoprostanes are derivatized with N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide and F2- isoprostanes quantified by gas chromatography/negative ion chemical ionization mass spectrometry (GC/NICI-MS) using [2H4]-PGF2a (Cayman Chemical, Ann Arbor, MI) as an internal standard.

[0255] 7. HPLC Analysis for 8-Hydroxy-2-Deoxyguanosine in Lung DNA: DNA from mouse lung tissue was obtained by a chloroform/isoamyl alcohol extraction of proteinase K digested lung homogenates. The purified DNA was then hydrolyzed to nucleosides with nuclease PI and alkaline phosphatase. Samples were analyzed for 8- hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine (8OH2dG) and 2-deoxyguanosine (2dG) by HPLC coupled with coulometric electrochemical and UV detection (CoulAnay Model 5600; ESA Inc., Chelmford, MA) for 8OH2dG and 2dG respectively. Sample analysis was done using a 4.6 x 150 mm, C-18 reverse phase column (YMCbasic®; YMC Inc., Wilmington, NC) with a mobile phase of 100 mM sodium acetate in 5% methanol at pH 5.2. UV detects 2dG at 265nm while 8OH2dG was detected elecfrochemically with electrode potentials of 285, 365 and 435 mV. Under these conditions, 2dG and 8OH2dG had retention times of approximately 7.4 and 9.5 minutes respectively. Nucleoside concentrations were calculated from standard curves generated daily with freshly prepared standards.

[0256] 8. Pseudomonas killing assay. This assay was derived from an assay used to study bacterial killing by neutrophils (Hampton, M.B. 1999 "Methods for quantifying phagocytosis and bacterial killing by human neutrophils" J. nmunol. Methods 232: 15- 22). Inoculums of Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA01) are grown in LB media in the presence or absence of mouse BALF and viability assessed at various time points
(usually 4 to 8 hours). Mice are anesthetized with pentobarbital followed by exsanguinations by direct cardiac puncture.

[0257] Approximately 1 ml of blood is collected in heparinized tubes and plasma prepared by centrifugation and stored at -80°C until use. BALF was collected using one 1-mL aliquot of sterile phosphate buffered, pH 7.4 (PB). The aliquot is centrifuged (2000 x g for 5 minutes at 4 °C) to recover cells. An aliquot ofthe cell free BALF supernatant is acidified with 5% -phosphoric acid and the supernatant retained and stored at -70 °C for subsequent analyses. The remaining cell free BALF is used for testing in its effect in host defense in the Pseudomonas growth inhibition assay. The right and left lungs are then removed and either quick-frozen in liquid nitrogen or fixed for immunocytochemistry.

[0258] To minimize GSH loss during the evaluation, BALF is acidified with 5% m- phosphoric acid (150 μL/mL), cooled on ice and centrifuged (10,000 x g for 10 min. at 4 °C) to remove precipitated proteins. The lung tissue, approximately 20 mg ofthe ground tissue is dissolved in 600 μL of PBS, acidified with 50 μL of 5% m-phosphoric acid, cooled on ice, and centrifuged (10,000 x g for 10 min. at 4 °C) to remove precipitated proteins. GSH and GSSG in BALF and tissues are analyzed by HPLC coupled with coulometric electrochemical detection (CoulAπay Model 5600; ESA Inc., Chelmford, MA). Sample analysis was done using a 7 x 53 mm C-18 reverse phase (Platinum EPS C18 100A 3μm, Alltech Associates Inc., Deerfield, IL) and a mobile phase of 125 mM potassium acetate in 1% acetonitrile at pH of 3.0. The electrode potentials in a four- channel electrode array were set at 100, 215, 485 and 570 mV. Under these conditions, GSH exhibited a retention time of 2.7 minutes with a signal distributed across channels 2, 3 and 4; GSSG exhibited a retention time of 4.2 minutes with a signal confined to channel 4. Concentrations of GSH and GSSG from a lOμL injection can be determined from a five-point calibration curve generated from standards prepared fresh daily.

[0259] Bacterial viability is assessed by the loss of ability of bacteria to form colonies after plating on nutrient agar. In preliminary studies it was determined that a 1 :2,000,000
dilution of the culture plated on agar overnight gives a good number of CFUs (colony forming units) with the PA01 strain (see preliminary data). To control for dilutional effects of the BALF we control with the same % of PBS. This assay provides us with a functional endpoint to assess changes in host defense ofthe BALF.

[0260] 9. Cytokine Analyses. Levels of TNF-α, MIP-2 and IL-10 will be measured on 50 μl BALF using commercial ELISA kits (MTAOO, MM200 & M1000, R&D Systems, Minneapolis, MN). These cytokines are sunogate markers of inflammation. TNF- α and MIP-2 serve as pro-inflammatory cytokine markers and IL-10 serves as an anti- inflammatory cytokine marker; These markers are either elevated (TNF- α, MIP-2) or depressed (IL-10) in CF BALF.

[0261] 10. Histopathology. Mice from each group will be used for histopathology. Mice will be anesthetized with avertin and their trachea cannulated and instilled with 2% parafonnaldehyde plus 2% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4. After 10 minutes of fixation within the chest cavity, lungs are removed and 2 mm slices are cut and immersion fixed in 4% parafonnaldehyde for overnight fixation and embedded in parafilm. For electron microscopy, 2 mm slices are placed in 2% glutaraldehyde for four hours then cubed into 2 x 2 x 2 blocks and washed in cacodylate buffer and post-fixed with 2% OsO4. The blocks are dehydrated in a graded series of ethanol, transfened to propylene oxide, and embedded in Epox. A diamond knife is used to cut thin sections and placed on a 200 mesh uncoated grid. Sections are stained with uranyl acetate and lead citrate prior to viewing. Sections will be viewed for both extent and severity of tissue injury and inflammatory cell infiltration.

claim.claim-text: Claims:

1. A method comprising: contacting one or more cells with an agent to increase transport of at least one thiol-containing compound; and modulating secretion of thiol-containing compound(s) from the cell (s).
2. The method of claim 1 , wherein modulating the secretion of thiol-containing compounds comprises increasing the excretion of thiol-containing compounds
3. The method of claim 1 , wherein the agent activates a thiol-containing compound transporter system localized on the apical surface ofthe cell(s).
4. The method of claim 3, wherein the transporter system comprises an ABC (ATP- binding cassette) transporter.

5. The method of claim 4, the ABC transporter comprises at least one fransporter selected from the group consisting of an MRP-2 (multi-drag resistance-associated protein) transporter; an MRP-1 (multi-drug resistance-associated protein) transporter; an MDR-1 (multi-drag resistance) fransporter and cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
6. The method of claim 1, wherein the cell comprises a lung cell.
7. The method of claim 6, further comprising replenishing thiol-containing compounds in the lung epithelial lining fluid (ELF).
8. The method of claim 1, wherein the agent comprises a gene vector encoding a thiol-containing compound transporter.
9. The method of claim 1 , wherein the agent comprises a protein.
10. The method of claim 1, wherein the agent comprises a thiol-containing compound transporter gene promoter.

11. A method comprising, contacting one or more cells with a composition comprising at least one molecule selected from the group consisting of a flavone, a flavanone, a isoflavone, a flavanol, a benzoic acid derivative, an indole derivative, a 1,4-Naphthoquinone, a 3-Phenylcoumarin, a 2-phenyl-4-quinoline, a 1-thioflavone, and a thioflavin; and increasing the secretion of thiol-containing compound(s) from the cell.

12. The method of claim 11, wherein the composition comprises at least one molecule selected from the group consisting of sulfasalzine, 2-chloro-3- mo hilino- 1 ,4-Naphthoquinone, 4-methyl-3-phenylcoumarin, methyl-2-phenyl- 4-quinolonecarbonylate, 2-phenylthiochromen-flavone, thioflavin T (basic yellow 1), daidzein and ebselen.
13. The method of claim 12, wherein the composition comprises sulfasalzine or a modified sulfasalazine or a sulfasalazine analog.
14. A method comprising, contacting one or more cells with at least one of a composition comprising a steroid; and increasing the secretion of thiol-containing compound(s) from the cell.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein the steroid is dexamethasone or a modified dexamethasone or a dexamethasone analog.

16. A method comprising, contacting one or more cells with a composition comprising at least one naturally occurring alkaloid; and increasing the secretion of thiol-containing compound(s) from the cell(s).
17. The method of claim 16, wherein the naturally occurring alkaloid composition is berberine or a modified berberine or a berberine analog.
18. The method of claim 16, wherein the naturally occurring alkaloid composition is hydrazine or a modified hydrazine or a hydrazine analog.

19. A method comprising; identifying a subject with a deficiency of a thiol-containing compounds; and contacting one or more cells of said subject with an agent to increase transport of thiol-containing compounds; and modulating secretion of thiol-containing compound(s) from the cell (s).
20. The method of claim 19, wherein the deficiency comprises a lung disease.

21. The method of claim 20, wherein the lung disease comprises at least one disease selected from the group consisting of cystic fibrosis, asthma, emphysema, chronic obstructive lung disease, infant respiratory distress syndrome, interstitial lung disease or adult respiratory distress syndrome, Adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), sepsis, and Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD).
22. The method of claim 21, wherein the lung disease comprises cystic fibrosis.
23. The method of claim 19, wherein the thiol-containing compound deficiency comprises a pancreatic disease.
24. The method of claim 19, wherein the thiol-containing compound deficiency comprises a bowel disorder.
25. The method of claim 24, wherein the bowel-disorder comprises at least one disease selected from the group consisting of Crohn's disease, Colitis and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
26. The method of claim 19, wherein the deficiency is caused by an infection.
27. The method of claim 26, wherein the infection comprises a bacterial or a viral infection.
28. The method of claim 26, wherein the infection comprises an infection in the lung.

29. The method of claim 19, wherein the deficiency comprises at least one disease selected from the group consisting of a vascular disease, a neurodegenerative disease, a biliary disease, and an inflammatory disease.
30. The method of claim 19, wherein the deficiency contributes to male infertility.

31. The method of claim 19, wherein the agent is administered by at least one route selected from the group consisting of intranasally, intratracheally, by inhalation, intravenously, intraperitoneally, subcutaneously, intradermally, intranodally, intramuscularly, orally, rectally, intravaginally, and topically.
32. The method of claim 31 , wherein the agent is administered orally or by inhalation.
33. The method of claim 19, wherein the agent is administered in a pharmaceutically acceptable delivery vehicle.
34. The method of claiml9, wherein the thiol-containing compound transporter is an ABC transporter.
35. The method of claim 19, wherein the cell is a lung cell.

36. The method of claim 19, wherein the agent comprises one or more molecules selected from the group consisting of a flavone, flavanone, isoflavone, flavanol,
benzoic acid derivative, indole derivative, 1,4-Naphthoquinone, 3- Phenylcoumarin, 2-phenyl-4-quinoline, 1-thioflavone, and thioflavin.
37. The method of claim 19, wherein the agent comprises a gene encoding an ABC transporter.
38. The method of claim 19, wherein the agent comprises an ABC transporter protein.

39. A system for identifying thiol-containing compound transporter modulators comprising; one or more cells; a potential thiol-containing compound fransporter modulating agent; and a thiol-containing compound measuring device.
40. The system of claim 39, further comprising an adherence filter.
41. The system of claim 40, wherein said device measures excretion of thiol- containing compounds from the apical surface ofthe one or more cells.
42. The system of claim 39, wherein the cell comprises a lung carcinoma cell line.
43. The system of claim 39, wherein the cell is contained in a whole animal.
44. The system of claim 40, further comprising the lung of a whole animal.
45. The system of claim 37, wherein the thiol-containing compound measuring . device comprises an HPLC (High Performance Liquid Chromatography).

46. A kit comprising: a delivery lumen; at least one agent, delivered from the delivery lumen,
the at least one agent comprising a compound capable of increasing transport of thiol-containing compounds
47. The kit of claim 46, wherein the delivery lumen further comprises a delivery lumen of an inhalant device.
48. The kit of claim 46, wherein the agent comprises sulfasalazine.
49. A composition comprising: a delivery vehicle; and a compound capable of modulating the transport of thiol-containing compounds.
50. The composition of claim 49, wherein the delivery vehicle comprises a bioerodible particle.
51. The composition of claim 49, wherein the compound comprises a naturally occurring alkaloid.

52. A method comprising: contacting one or more cells with an agent to increase fransport of at least one thiol-containing compound; and modulating transport of thiol-containing compound(s) in the cell (s).
53. The method of claim 52, wherein modulating incorporation further comprises modulating transport of thiol-containing compound(s) in a compartment within the cell (s).
54. The method of claim 53, wherein the compartment within the cell(s) is the mitochondria.
